author: Michael Silverman
title: Ruben Amaro Jr. eager to begin 'unusual' move to Red Sox 1B coach
text:
Ruben Amaro Jr. eager to begin 'unusual' move to Red Sox 1B coach Michael Silverman Ruben Amaro/File comments Tweet Ruben Amaro Jr. acknowledged his career path is taking an unconventional turn but the new Red Sox first base coach is all aboard for achieving a traditional goal: Winning a World Series.
“I guess it is unusual but for me I've always had an itch to be back on the field,” said Amaro, the former Phillies GM, in a conference call today.
He cited working with the young players as being a chief motivating factor.
“Clearly, with Mookie Betts, Jackie Bradley, Rusney Castillo, Brock Holt, Travis Shaw, Bryce Brentz possibly — I know he's recovering — there's some talented young men, there's no question about it, I'm excited about it,” said Amaro. “We're in a world of youthful energy and quality.
“I'll do my best to teach what I've learned over the years, and some of the things I've learned from some great outfield instructors myself to try to get these guys to understand the importance and they had great success in the second half of the year with that trio of outfielders that were frankly outstanding. I'm just going to try to do my best to continue the process and the growth in their careers and the growth of the Red Sox as we move forward.”
Manager John Farrell was enthusiastic about Amaro's characteristics, one being his eagerness to help.
“When Dave came in and felt like there was a need to mix things up, to change things and add a different mix to our staff you start to go back through and think about the potential candidates,” said Farrell, who played with Amaro in Cleveland. “But having known certainly Ruben as a former teammate and reading there were some articles written on his potential interest in getting back to the field (I) lobbed a call to him. Other than knowing Ruben's intelligence from who he was as a player, we're talking about someone who had to learn all three outfield positions as a former infielder. The steps he went through as a player certainly has given him an incredible reference point to go back to to begin to teach and to help others. It's his personality, it's his intelligence.”
Amaro, 50, spent the last 10 years as Philadelphia's GM. He was the assistant GM when the Phillies won the World Series in 2008 and was the GM when the Phillies fell to the Yankees in the 2009 World Series. The Phillies dismissed him last month.
Amaro played for eight seasons between 1991 and 1998 with the Phillies, Angels and Indians. He was a career .235 hitter with 16 home runs and 100 RBI in 485 games.
Amaro is the son of Ruben Amaro Sr, an 11-year major leaguer and together they are the only father-and-son combination to play for the Phillies. A graduate of Stanford University (human biology major), Amaro played on the school's College World Series championship team in 1987.
Amaro replaces first base coach Arnie Beyeler, who was not retained by the Red Sox at the season's end. All other coaches will be returning.
